Read file: tasks.md

---



---

Adding front-end unit tests now is low-risk and high-value; full-stack Playwright tests are much heavier and likely to break without extra infrastructure around LM Studio.

1. Front-end tests (Jest/Vitest + React Testing Library)
   â€¢ Pros  
     â€“ Fast, run entirely in Node, no need to talk to your LLM or Docker services  
     â€“ You can mock your Axios/apiClient calls (e.g. with Jestâ€™s `msw` or simple spies)  
     â€“ Quickly catch regressions in UI logic, props, state, styling  
   â€¢ Cons  
     â€“ Youâ€™ll need to write the mocks for each endpoint call  
   â†’ Recommendation: âœ… Definitely worth doing now. Start by writing a few smoke tests for core components (ChatPanel, FileUploader, SummarisePanel), mocking out the API so they never actually hit LM Studio.

2. Playwright E2E tests  
   â€¢ Pros  
     â€“ Exercising the fully wired-up app (React â†’ FastAPI â†’ ChromaDB â†’ LM Studio)  
     â€“ Catches integration issues you wonâ€™t see in unit tests  
   â€¢ Cons  
     â€“ You must have LM Studio running on port 1234 in CI (or spin up a container), plus MinIO, Postgres, ChromaDB, backend serverâ€¦  
     â€“ Very fragile if any network/service is flaky or slow  
     â€“ CI machines rarely have LM Studio installed â†’ youâ€™ll need to mock or containerize it anyway  
   â†’ Recommendation: postpone or scaffold only. Unless you can containerize LM Studio (or provide a dummy stub server in CI), full-stack E2E will frequently fail. Itâ€™s a great goal, but Iâ€™d focus first on front-end unit tests and perhaps smoke tests against a mocked backend (e.g., spin up FastAPI with a fake â€œpingâ€ endpoint), then layer in real Playwright tests once your CI can reliably bring up all services.

ELI5:  
â€¢ Unit tests for your React pieces are like testing individual Lego bricksâ€”you pull them off the board and make sure each one clicks together properly.  
â€¢ Playwright E2E tests are like building the entire castle, moat, and drawbridge and then rolling a toy knight through itâ€”great for catching real-world breakages, but you need to set up the whole scene perfectly every time, which is a lot more work and can fall over if anything upstream (like LM Studio) isnâ€™t 100% stable.

---

      runs-on: ubuntu-latest
      needs: backend-tests
+     steps:
+       - uses: actions/checkout@v4
+       - name: Set up Node.js
+         uses: actions/setup-node@v3
+         with:
+           node-version: '20'
+           cache: pnpm
+       - name: Install pnpm
+         run: npm install -g pnpm
+       - name: Install dependencies
+         run: |
+           cd frontend
+           pnpm install
+       - name: Run frontend unit tests
+         run: |
+           cd frontend
+           pnpm test -- --coverage

+ import { ChakraProvider } from '@chakra-ui/react';
+ 
+ describe('FileUploader', () => {
+   it('renders dropzone area', () => {
+     render(
+       <ChakraProvider>
+         <FileUploader />
+       </ChakraProvider>
+     );
+     expect(screen.getByText(/Drag & drop files here, or click to select files/i)).toBeInTheDocument();
+   });
+ 
+   it('does not show upload button when no files are selected', () => {
+     render(
+       <ChakraProvider>
+         <FileUploader />
+       </ChakraProvider>
+     );
+     expect(screen.queryByRole('button', { name: /Upload Selected/i })).toBeNull();
+   });
+ });

```diff
- 
+ FROM node:20-alpine AS builder
+ WORKDIR /app
+ 
+ # Copy package files and install dependencies
+ COPY frontend/package.json frontend/pnpm-lock.yaml ./
+ RUN npm install -g pnpm
+ RUN pnpm install
+ 
+ # Copy source code and build
+ COPY frontend/ ./
+ RUN pnpm build
+ 
+ # Stage 2: Serve static content with Nginx
+ FROM nginx:stable-alpine AS production
+ # Remove default nginx static files
+ RUN rm -rf /usr/share/nginx/html/*
+ # Copy build output
+ COPY --from=builder /app/dist /usr/share/nginx/html
+ 
+ # Expose port
+ EXPOSE 80
+ CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"] 
```
